3.caption: Financial
3.description: Any financially-related sensitive information or Cardholder Data (CHD). E.g., banking account numbers, credit card numbers, International Banking Account Numbers (IBAN), SWIFT codes, etc.

6.caption: Security
6.description: Any sensitive security-related data such as passwords, passkeys, IP addresses, API keys, credentials and similar secrets. E.g., AWS Access Secret Key, SaaS API Keys, user passwords, database credentials, etc.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the data_type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Personal
1.description: Any Personally Identifiable Information (PII), Electronic Personal Health Information (ePHI), or similarly personal information. E.g., full name, home address, date of birth, etc.

2.caption: Governmental
2.description: Any sensitive government identification number related to a person or other classified material. E.g., Passport numbers, driver license numbers, business identification, taxation identifiers, etc.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of data classification or a multi-variate classification made up of several other classification categories.

4.caption: Business
4.description: Any business-specific sensitive data such as intellectual property, trademarks, copyrights, human resource data, Board of Directors meeting minutes, and similar.

5.caption: Military and Law Enforcement
5.description: Any mission-specific sensitive data for military, law enforcement, or other government agencies such as specifically classified data, weapon systems information, or other planning data.

classifier_details.caption: Classifier Details
classifier_details.description: Describes details about the classifier used for data classification.

confidentiality.caption: Confidentiality
confidentiality.description: The file content confidentiality, normalized to the confidentiality_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidentiality_id.caption: Confidentiality ID
confidentiality_id.description: The normalized identifier of the file content confidentiality indicator.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidentiality is not mapped. See the confidentiality attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

data_lifecycle_state.caption: Data Lifecycle State
data_lifecycle_state.description: The name of the stage or state that the data was in. E.g., Data-at-Rest, Data-in-Transit, etc.

data_lifecycle_state_id.caption: Data Lifecycle State ID
data_lifecycle_state_id.description: The stage or state that the data was in when it was assessed or scanned by a data security tool.

3.caption: Data in-Use
3.description: The data was being processed, accessed, or read by a system, making it active in memory or CPU. E.g., sensitive data in a Business Intelligence tool, ePHI being processed in an EHR application or a user viewing data stored in a spreadsheet or PDF.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The data lifecycle state is unknown.

1.caption: Data at-Rest
1.description: The data was stored on physical or logical media and was not actively moving through the network nor was being processed. E.g., data stored in a database, PDF files in a file share, or EHR records in object storage.

2.caption: Data in-Transit
2.description: The data was actively moving through the network or from one physical or logical location to another. E.g., emails being send, data replication or Change Data Capture (CDC) streams, or sensitive data processed on an API.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The data lifecycle state is not mapped. See the data_lifecycle_state attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

detection_pattern.caption: Detection Pattern
detection_pattern.description: Specific pattern, algorithm, fingerprint, or model used for detection.

detection_system.caption: Detection System
detection_system.description: The name of the type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from. E.g., Endpoint, Secure Email Gateway, etc.

detection_system_id.caption: Detection System ID
detection_system_id.description: The type of data security tool or system that the finding, detection, or alert originated from.

3.caption: Mobile Device Management
3.description: A Mobile Device Management (MDM) or Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on mobile devices (e.g., cellphones, tablets, End User Devices [EUDs]).

6.caption: Secure Email Gateway
6.description: A Secure Email Gateway (SEG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies within email systems. E.g., Microsoft Defender for Office, Google Workspaces.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The type is not mapped. See the detection_system attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Endpoint
1.description: A dedicated agent or sensor installed on a device, either a dedicated data security tool or an Endpoint Detection & Response (EDR) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., Forcepoint DLP, Symantec DLP, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint (MDE).

2.caption: DLP Gateway
2.description: A Data Loss Prevention (DLP) gateway that is positioned in-line of an information store such as a network share, a database, or otherwise that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.

99.caption: Other
99.description: Any other type of detection system or a multi-variate system made up of several other systems.

4.caption: Data Discovery & Classification
4.description: A tool that actively identifies and classifies sensitive data in digital media and information stores in accordance with a policy or automated functionality. E.g, Amazon Macie, Microsoft Purview.

5.caption: Secure Web Gateway
5.description: A Secure Web Gateway (SWG) is any tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies at a network-edge such as within a proxy or firewall service.

7.caption: Digital Rights Management
7.description: A Digital Rights Management (DRM) or a dedicated Information Rights Management (IRM) are tools which can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies on digital media via policy or user access rights.

8.caption: Cloud Access Security Broker
8.description: A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies in-line to cloud systems such as the public cloud or Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) tool. E.g., Forcepoint CASB, SkyHigh Security.

9.caption: Database Activity Monitoring
9.description: A Database Activity Monitoring (DAM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies as part of a dedicated database or warehouse monitoring solution.

10.caption: Application-Level DLP
10.description: A built in Data Loss Prevention (DLP) or other data security capability within a tool or platform such as an Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) or Customer Relations Management (CRM) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies.

11.caption: Developer Security
11.description: Any Developer Security tool such as an Infrastructure-as-Code (IAC) security scanner, Secrets Detection, or Secure Software Development Lifecycle (SSDLC) tool that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies. E.g., TruffleHog, GitGuardian, Git-Secrets.

12.caption: Data Security Posture Management
12.description: A Data Security Posture Management (DSPM) tool is a continuous monitoring and data discovery solution that can detect sensitive data and/or enforce data security policies for local and cloud environments. E.g., Cyera, Sentra, IBM Polar Security.

discovery_details.caption: Discovery Details
discovery_details.description: Details about the data discovered by classification job.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description: Details about the policy that triggered the finding.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The source URL pointing towards the full classifcation job details.

status_details.caption: Status Details
status_details.description: The contextual description of the status, status_id value.

status_id.caption: Status ID
status_id.description: The normalized status identifier of the classification job.

3.caption: Fail
3.description: The classification job failed for the evaluated resource.

1.caption: Complete
1.description: The classification job completed for the evaluated resource.

2.caption: Partial
2.description: The classification job partially completed for the evaluated resource.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The classification job type id is not mapped.

dns_query.caption: DNS Query
dns_query.name: dns_query
dns_query.description: The DNS query object represents a specific request made to the Domain Name System (DNS) to retrieve information about a domain or perform a DNS operation. This object encapsulates the necessary attributes and methods to construct and send DNS queries, specify the query type (e.g., A, AAAA, MX).

type.caption: Resource Record Type
type.description: The type of resource records being queried. See RFC1035. For example: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, and NS.

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The hostname or domain being queried. For example: www.example.com

class.caption: Resource Record Class
class.description: The class of resource records being queried. See RFC1035. For example: IN.

opcode.caption: DNS Opcode
opcode.description: The DNS opcode specifies the type of the query message.

opcode_id.caption: DNS Opcode ID
opcode_id.description: The DNS opcode ID specifies the normalized query message type as defined in RFC-5395.

3.caption: Reserved
3.description: Reserved, not used

6.caption: DSO Message
6.description: DNS Stateful Operations (DSO)

1.caption: Inverse Query
1.description: Inverse query, obsolete

2.caption: Status
2.description: Server status request

99.caption: Other
99.description: The DNS Opcode is not defined by the RFC. See the opcode attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: Notify
4.description: Zone change notification

5.caption: Update
5.description: Dynamic DNS update

packet_uid.caption: Packet UID
packet_uid.description: The DNS packet identifier assigned by the program that generated the query. The identifier is copied to the response.

hassh.caption: HASSH
hassh.name: hassh
hassh.description: The HASSH object contains SSH network fingerprinting values for specific client/server implementations. It provides a standardized way of identifying and categorizing SSH connections based on their unique characteristics and behavior.

algorithm.caption: Algorithm
algorithm.description: The concatenation of key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms (separated by ';'). NOTE: This is not the underlying algorithm for the hash implementation.

fingerprint.caption: Fingerprint
fingerprint.description: The hash of the key exchange, encryption, authentication and compression algorithms.

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.name: cvss
cvss.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) object provides a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The CVSS version. For example: 3.1.

depth.caption: CVSS Depth
depth.description: The CVSS depth represents a depth of the equation used to calculate CVSS score.

severity.caption: Severity
severity.description:
The Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) Qualitative Severity Rating. A textual representation of the numeric score.

CVSS v2.0
  • Low (0.0 – 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 – 6.9)
  • High (7.0 – 10.0)

CVSS v3.0
  • None (0.0)
  • Low (0.1 - 3.9)
  • Medium (4.0 - 6.9)
  • High (7.0 - 8.9)
  • Critical (9.0 - 10.0)

metrics.caption: Metrics
metrics.description: The Common Vulnerability Scoring System metrics. This attribute contains information on the CVE's impact. If the CVE has been analyzed, this attribute will contain any CVSSv2 or CVSSv3 information associated with the vulnerability. For example: { {"Access Vector", "Network"}, {"Access Complexity", "Low"}, ...}.

base_score.caption: Base Score
base_score.description: The CVSS base score. For example: 9.1.

overall_score.caption: Overall Score
overall_score.description: The CVSS overall score, impacted by base, temporal, and environmental metrics. For example: 9.1.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The source URL for the CVSS score. For example: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-44228

vector_string.caption: Vector String
vector_string.description: The CVSS vector string is a text representation of a set of CVSS metrics. It is commonly used to record or transfer CVSS metric information in a concise form. For example: 3.1/AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:H.

vendor_name.caption: Vendor Name
vendor_name.description: The vendor that provided the CVSS score. For example: NVD, REDHAT etc.

network_traffic.caption: Network Traffic
network_traffic.name: network_traffic
network_traffic.description: The Network Traffic object describes characteristics of network traffic. Network traffic refers to data moving across a network at a given point of time.

bytes_in.caption: Bytes In
bytes_in.description: The number of bytes sent from the destination to the source.

bytes_out.caption: Bytes Out
bytes_out.description: The number of bytes sent from the source to the destination.

chunks.caption: Chunks
chunks.description: The total number of chunks (in and out).

bytes.caption: Total Bytes
bytes.description: The total number of bytes (in and out).

bytes_missed.caption: Bytes Missed
bytes_missed.description: Indicates the number of bytes missed, which is representative of packet loss.

chunks_in.caption: Chunks In
chunks_in.description: The number of chunks sent from the destination to the source.

chunks_out.caption: Chunks Out
chunks_out.description: The number of chunks sent from the source to the destination.

packets.caption: Total Packets
packets.description: The total number of packets (in and out).

packets_in.caption: Packets In
packets_in.description: The number of packets sent from the destination to the source.

packets_out.caption: Packets Out
packets_out.description: The number of packets sent from the source to the destination.

load_balancer.caption: Load Balancer
load_balancer.name: load_balancer
load_balancer.description: The load balancer object describes the load balancer entity and contains additional information regarding the distribution of traffic across a network.

code.caption: Response Code
code.description: The numeric response status code detailing the connection from the load balancer to the destination target.

message.caption: Message
message.description: The load balancer message.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the load balancer.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address of the load balancer node that handled the client request. Note: the load balancer may have other IP addresses, and this is not an IP address of the target/distribution endpoint - see dst_endpoint.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier for the load balancer.

metrics.caption: Metrics
metrics.description: General purpose metrics associated with the load balancer.

classification.caption: Classification
classification.description: The request classification as defined by the load balancer.

dst_endpoint.caption: Destination Endpoint
dst_endpoint.description: The destination to which the load balancer is distributing traffic.

endpoint_connections.caption: Endpoint Connections
endpoint_connections.description: An object detailing the load balancer connection attempts and responses.

status_detail.caption: Status Detail
status_detail.description: The status detail contains additional status information about the load balancer distribution event.

table.caption: Table
table.name: table
table.description: The table object represents a table within a structured relational database or datastore, which contains columns and rows of data that are able to be create, updated, deleted and queried.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The table name, ordinarily as assigned by a database administrator.

size.caption: Size
size.description: The size of the data table in bytes.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the table.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the table.

groups.caption: Groups
groups.description: The group names to which the table belongs.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the table was known to have been created.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The most recent time when any changes, updates, or modifications were made within the table.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The most recent time when any changes, updates, or modifications were made within the table.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The time when the table was known to have been created.

email.caption: Email
email.name: email
email.description: The Email object describes the email metadata such as sender, recipients, and direction, and can include embedded URLs and files.

size.caption: Size
size.description: The size in bytes of the email, including attachments.

uid.caption: Email Thread UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the email thread.

files.caption: Files
files.description: The files embedded or attached to the email.

from.caption: From
from.description: The machine-readable email header From values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com

cc.caption: Cc
cc.description: The machine-readable email header Cc values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com.

to.caption: To
to.description: The machine-readable email header To values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com

subject.caption: Subject
subject.description: The email header Subject value, as defined by RFC 5322.

cc_mailboxes.caption: Cc Mailboxes
cc_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header Cc Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

delivered_to.caption: Delivered To
delivered_to.description: The machine-readable Delivered-To email header field. For example example.user@usersdomain.com

delivered_to_list.caption: Delivered To
delivered_to_list.description: The machine-readable Delivered-To email header values. For example example.user@usersdomain.com

from_mailbox.caption: From Mailbox
from_mailbox.description: The human-readable email header From Mailbox value. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.

http_headers.caption: HTTP Headers
http_headers.description: Additional HTTP headers of an HTTP request or response.

is_read.caption: Read
is_read.description: The indication of whether the email has been read.

message_uid.caption: Message UID
message_uid.description: The email header Message-ID value, as defined by RFC 5322.

reply_to.caption: Reply To
reply_to.description: The machine-readable email header Reply-To values, as defined by RFC 5322. For example example.user@usersdomain.com

reply_to_mailboxes.caption: Reply To Mailboxes
reply_to_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header Reply To Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.

smtp_from.caption: SMTP From
smtp_from.description: The value of the SMTP MAIL FROM command.

smtp_to.caption: SMTP To
smtp_to.description: The value of the SMTP envelope RCPT TO command.

to_mailboxes.caption: To Mailboxes
to_mailboxes.description: The human-readable email header To Mailbox values. For example 'Example User <example.user@usersdomain.com>'.

urls.caption: URLs
urls.description: The URLs embedded in the email.

x_originating_ip.caption: X-Originating-IP
x_originating_ip.description: The X-Originating-IP header identifying the emails originating IP address(es).

object.caption: Object
object.name: object
object.description: An unordered collection of attributes. It defines a set of attributes available in all objects. It can be also used as a generic object to log objects that are not otherwise defined by the schema.

anomaly_analysis.caption: Anomaly Analysis
anomaly_analysis.name: anomaly_analysis
anomaly_analysis.description: Describes the analysis of activity patterns and anomalies of target entities to identify potential security threats, performance issues, or other deviations from established baselines. This includes monitoring and analyzing user interactions, API usage, resource utilization, access patterns and other measured indicators.

analysis_targets.caption: Analysis Targets
analysis_targets.description: The analysis targets define the scope of monitored activities, specifying what entities, systems or processes are analyzed for activity patterns.

anomalies.caption: Anomalies
anomalies.description: List of detected activities that significantly deviate from the established baselines. This can include unusual access patterns, unexpected user-agents, abnormal API usage, suspicious traffic spikes, unauthorized access attempts, and other activities that may indicate potential security threats or system issues.

baselines.caption: Baselines
baselines.description: List of established patterns representing normal activity that serve as reference points for anomaly detection. This includes typical user interaction patterns like common user-agents, expected API access frequencies and patterns, standard resource utilization levels, and regular traffic flows. These baselines help establish what constitutes 'normal' activity in the system.

kernel_driver.caption: Kernel Extension
kernel_driver.name: kernel_driver
kernel_driver.description: The Kernel Extension object describes a kernel driver that has been loaded or unloaded into the operating system (OS) kernel.

file.caption: File
file.description: The driver/extension file object.

network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint
network_endpoint.name: network_endpoint
network_endpoint.description: The Network Endpoint object describes characteristics of a network endpoint. These can be a source or destination of a network connection.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the endpoint or was last logged into it.

port.caption: Port
port.description: The port used for communication within the network connection.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The network endpoint type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

domain.caption: Domain
domain.description: The name of the domain that the endpoint belongs to or that corresponds to the endpoint.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the endpoint.

mac.caption: MAC Address
mac.description: The Media Access Control (MAC) address of the endpoint.

3.caption: Laptop
3.description: A laptop computer.

6.caption: Virtual
6.description: A virtual machine.

1.caption: Server
1.description: A server.

2.caption: Desktop
2.description: A desktop computer.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: Tablet
4.description: A tablet computer.

5.caption: Mobile
5.description: A mobile phone.

7.caption: IOT
7.description: An IOT (Internet of Things) device.

8.caption: Browser
8.description: A web browser.

9.caption: Firewall
9.description: A networking firewall.

10.caption: Switch
10.description: A networking switch.

11.caption: Hub
11.description: A networking hub.

12.caption: Router
12.description: A networking router.

14.caption: IPS
14.description: An intrusion prevention system.

15.caption: Load Balancer
15.description: A Load Balancer device.

13.caption: IDS
13.description: An intrusion detection system.

agent_list.caption: Agent List
agent_list.description: A list of agent objects associated with a device, endpoint, or resource.

autonomous_system.caption: Autonomous System
autonomous_system.description: The Autonomous System details associated with an IP address.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

instance_uid.caption: Instance ID
instance_uid.description: The unique identifier of a VM instance.

interface_name.caption: Network Interface Name
interface_name.description: The name of the network interface (e.g. eth2).

interface_uid.caption: Network Interface ID
interface_uid.description: The unique identifier of the network interface.

intermediate_ips.caption: Intermediate IP Addresses
intermediate_ips.description: The intermediate IP Addresses. For example, the IP addresses in the HTTP X-Forwarded-For header.

isp.caption: ISP Name
isp.description: The name of the Internet Service Provider (ISP).

isp_org.caption: ISP Org
isp_org.description: The organization name of the Internet Service Provider (ISP). This represents the parent organization or company that owns/operates the ISP. For example, Comcast Corporation would be the ISP org for Xfinity internet service. This attribute helps identify the ultimate provider when ISPs operate under different brand names.

namespace_pid.caption: Namespace PID
namespace_pid.description: If running under a process namespace (such as in a container), the process identifier within that process namespace.

proxy_endpoint.caption: Proxy Endpoint
proxy_endpoint.description: The network proxy information pertaining to a specific endpoint. This can be used to describe information pertaining to network address translation (NAT).

subnet_uid.caption: Subnet UID
subnet_uid.description: The unique identifier of a virtual subnet.

svc_name.caption: Service Name
svc_name.description: The service name in service-to-service connections. For example, AWS VPC logs the pkt-src-aws-service and pkt-dst-aws-service fields identify the connection is coming from or going to an AWS service.

vpc_uid.caption: VPC UID
vpc_uid.description: The unique identifier of the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC).

zone.caption: Network Zone
zone.description: The network zone or LAN segment.

edge.caption: Edge
edge.name: edge
edge.description: Represents a connection or relationship between two nodes in a graph.

data.caption: Data
data.description: Additional data about the edge such as weight, distance, or custom properties.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The human-readable name or label for the edge.

relation.caption: Relation
relation.description: The type of relationship between nodes (e.g. is-attached-to , depends-on, etc).

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: Unique identifier of the edge.

source.caption: Source
source.description: The unique identifier of the node where the edge originates.

target.caption: Target
target.description: The unique identifier of the node where the edge terminates.

is_directed.caption: Directed
is_directed.description: Indicates whether the edge is (true) or undirected (false).

ldap_person.caption: LDAP Person
ldap_person.name: ldap_person
ldap_person.description: The additional LDAP attributes that describe a person.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location associated with a user. This is typically the user's usual work location.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The labels associated with the user. For example in AD this could be the userType, employeeType. For example: Member, Employee.

manager.caption: Manager
manager.description: The user's manager. This helps in understanding an org hierarchy. This should only ever be populated once in an event. I.e. there should not be a manager's manager in an event.

tags.caption: Tags
tags.description: The list of tags; {key:value} pairs associated to the user.

cost_center.caption: Cost Center
cost_center.description: The cost center associated with the user.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The timestamp when the user was created.

deleted_time.caption: Deleted Time
deleted_time.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.

display_name.caption: Display Name
display_name.description: The display name of the LDAP person. According to RFC 2798, this is the preferred name of a person to be used when displaying entries.

email_addrs.caption: Email Addresses
email_addrs.description: A list of additional email addresses for the user.

employee_uid.caption: Employee ID
employee_uid.description: The employee identifier assigned to the user by the organization.

given_name.caption: Given Name
given_name.description: The given or first name of the user.

hire_time.caption: Hire Time
hire_time.description: The timestamp when the user was or will be hired by the organization.

last_login_time.caption: Last Login
last_login_time.description: The last time when the user logged in.

ldap_cn.caption: LDAP Common Name
ldap_cn.description: The LDAP and X.500 commonName attribute, typically the full name of the person. For example, John Doe.

ldap_dn.caption: LDAP Distinguished Name
ldap_dn.description: The X.500 Distinguished Name (DN) is a structured string that uniquely identifies an entry, such as a user, in an X.500 directory service For example, cn=John Doe,ou=People,dc=example,dc=com.

leave_time.caption: Leave Time
leave_time.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.

office_location.caption: Office Location
office_location.description: The primary office location associated with the user. This could be any string and isn't a specific address. For example, South East Virtual.

phone_number.caption: Telephone Number
phone_number.description: The telephone number of the user. Corresponds to the LDAP Telephone-Number CN.

surname.caption: Surname
surname.description: The last or family name for the user.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user entry was last modified.

deleted_time_dt.caption: Deleted Time
deleted_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was deleted. In Active Directory (AD), when a user is deleted they are moved to a temporary container and then removed after 30 days. So, this field can be populated even after a user is deleted for the next 30 days.

last_login_time_dt.caption: Last Login
last_login_time_dt.description: The last time when the user logged in.

hire_time_dt.caption: Hire Time
hire_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was or will be hired by the organization.

leave_time_dt.caption: Leave Time
leave_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user left or will be leaving the organization.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The timestamp when the user was created.

json_t.caption: JSON
json_t.description: Embedded JSON value. A value can be a string, or a number, or true or false or null, or an object or an array. These structures can be nested. See www.json.org.

datetime_t.caption: Datetime
datetime_t.description:
The Internet Date/Time format as defined in RFC-3339. For example:
2024-09-10T23:20:50.520Z,
2024-09-10 23:20:50.520789Z.

file_hash_t.caption: Hash
file_hash_t.description:
Hash. A unique value that corresponds to the content of the file, image, ja3_hash or hassh found in the schema. For example:
MD5: 3172ac7e2b55cbb81f04a6e65855a628.

file_path_t.caption: File Path
file_path_t.description:
The full path to the file. For example: For example:
c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe.

hostname_t.caption: Hostname
hostname_t.description:
Unique name assigned to a device connected to a computer network. It may be a fully qualified domain name (FQDN). For example:
r2-d2.example.com.,
mx.example.com

ip_t.caption: IP Address
ip_t.description:
Internet Protocol address (IP address), in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. For example:
192.168.200.24,
2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334.

resource_uid_t.caption: Resource UID
resource_uid_t.description: Resource unique identifier. For example, S3 Bucket name or EC2 Instance ID.

subnet_t.caption: Subnet
subnet_t.description:
The subnet represented in a CIDR notation, using the format network_address/prefix_length. The network_address can be in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. The prefix length indicates the number of bits used for the network portion, and the remaining bits are available for host addresses within that subnet. For example:
192.168.1.0/24,
2001:0db8:85a3:0000::/64

timestamp_t.caption: Timestamp
timestamp_t.description:
The timestamp format is the number of milliseconds since the Epoch 01/01/1970 00:00:00 UTC. For example:
1618524549901.

base_event.caption: Base Event
base_event.name: base_event

count.caption: Count
count.description: The number of times that events in the same logical group occurred during the event Start Time to End Time period.

message.caption: Message
message.description: The description of the event/finding, as defined by the source.

status.caption: Status
status.description: The event status, normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

time.caption: Event Time
time.description: The normalized event occurrence time or the finding creation time.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The metadata associated with the event or a finding.

start_time.caption: Start Time
start_time.description: The start time of a time period, or the time of the least recent event included in the aggregate event.

severity.caption: Severity
severity.description: The event/finding severity, normalized to the caption of the severity_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

duration.caption: Duration Milliseconds
duration.description: The event duration or aggregate time, the amount of time the event covers from start_time to end_time in milliseconds.

timezone_offset.caption: Timezone Offset
timezone_offset.description: The number of minutes that the reported event time is ahead or behind UTC, in the range -1,080 to +1,080.

activity_id.caption: Activity ID
activity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the activity that triggered the event.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event activity is not mapped. See the activity_name attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

class_uid.caption: Class ID
class_uid.description: The unique identifier of a class. A class describes the attributes available in an event.

0.caption: Base Event
0.description: The base event is a generic and concrete event. It also defines a set of attributes available in most event classes. As a generic event that does not belong to any event category, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the schema.

type_uid.caption: Type ID
type_uid.description: The event/finding type ID. It identifies the event's semantics and structure. The value is calculated by the logging system as: class_uid * 100 + activity_id.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

type_name.caption: Type Name
type_name.description: The event/finding type name, as defined by the type_uid.

category_uid.caption: Category ID
category_uid.description: The category unique identifier of the event.

observables.caption: Observables
observables.description: The observables associated with the event or a finding.

category_name.caption: Category
category_name.description: The event category name, as defined by category_uid value.

class_name.caption: Class
class_name.description: The event class name, as defined by class_uid value: Base Event.

end_time.caption: End Time
end_time.description: The end time of a time period, or the time of the most recent event included in the aggregate event.

activity_name.caption: Activity
activity_name.description: The event activity name, as defined by the activity_id.

enrichments.caption: Enrichments
enrichments.description:
The additional information from an external data source, which is associated with the event or a finding. For example add location information for the IP address in the DNS answers:

[{"name": "answers.ip", "value": "92.24.47.250", "type": "location", "data": {"city": "Socotra", "continent": "Asia", "coordinates": [-25.4153, 17.0743], "country": "YE", "desc": "Yemen"}}]

raw_data_size.caption: Raw Data Size
raw_data_size.description: The size of the raw data which was transformed into an OCSF event, in bytes.

severity_id.caption: Severity ID
severity_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the event/finding severity.

The normalized severity is a measurement the effort and expense required to manage and resolve an event or incident. Smaller numerical values represent lower impact events, and larger numerical values represent higher impact events.

3.caption: Medium
3.description: Action is required but the situation is not serious at this time.

6.caption: Fatal
6.description: An error occurred but it is too late to take remedial action.

1.caption: Informational
1.description: Informational message. No action required.

2.caption: Low
2.description: The user decides if action is needed.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event/finding severity is not mapped. See the severity attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: High
4.description: Action is required immediately.

5.caption: Critical
5.description: Action is required immediately and the scope is broad.

status_code.caption: Status Code
status_code.description:
The event status code, as reported by the event source.

For example, in a Windows Failed Authentication event, this would be the value of 'Failure Code', e.g. 0x18.

status_detail.caption: Status Detail
status_detail.description: The status detail contains additional information about the event/finding outcome.

status_id.caption: Status ID
status_id.description: The normalized identifier of the event status.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event status is not mapped. See the status attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

base_event.description: The base event is a generic and concrete event. It also defines a set of attributes available in most event classes. As a generic event that does not belong to any event category, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the schema.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.name: cloud
cloud.description: The attributes that describe information specific to Cloud services/applications.

api.caption: API Details
api.description: Describes details about a typical API (Application Programming Interface) call.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.description: Describes details about the Cloud environment where the event was originally created or logged.

container.caption: Container
container.name: container
container.description: The container context for a process.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

namespace_pid.caption: Namespace PID
namespace_pid.description: If running under a process namespace (such as in a container), the process identifier within that process namespace.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.name: data_classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification profile adds attributes to spepcific resource objects, allowing users to describe information about classifiers & data classification results.

data_classification.caption: Data Classification
data_classification.description: The Data Classification object includes information about data classification levels and data category types.

data_classifications.caption: Data Classification
data_classifications.description: A list of Data Classification objects, that include information about data classification levels and data category types, indentified by a classifier.

datetime.caption: Date/Time
datetime.name: datetime
datetime.description: This profile defines date/time attributes as defined in RFC-3339. For example 1985-04-12T23:20:50.52Z.

host.caption: Host
host.name: host
host.description: The attributes that identify host/device attributes.

device.caption: Device
device.description: An addressable device, computer system or host.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.description: The actor object describes details about the user/role/process that was the source of the activity. Note that this is not the threat actor of a campaign but may be part of a campaign.

incident.caption: Incident
incident.name: incident
incident.description: The attributes that add incident handling semantics to a Finding.

priority.caption: Priority
priority.description: The priority, normalized to the caption of the priority_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

ticket.caption: Ticket
ticket.description: The linked ticket in the ticketing system.

assignee.caption: Assignee
assignee.description: The details of the user assigned to an Incident.

assignee_group.caption: Assignee Group
assignee_group.description: The details of the group assigned to an Incident.

impact.caption: Impact
impact.description: The impact , normalized to the caption of the impact_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

impact_id.caption: Impact ID
impact_id.description: The normalized impact of the incident or finding. Per NIST, this is the magnitude of harm that can be expected to result from the consequences of unauthorized disclosure, modification, destruction, or loss of information or information system availability.

3.caption: High
3.description: The magnitude of harm is high.

1.caption: Low
1.description: The magnitude of harm is low.

2.caption: Medium
2.description: The magnitude of harm is moderate.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The impact is not mapped. See the impact attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: Critical
4.description: The magnitude of harm is high and the scope is widespread.

impact_score.caption: Impact Score
impact_score.description: The impact as an integer value of the finding, valid range 0-100.

is_suspected_breach.caption: Suspected Breach
is_suspected_breach.description: A determination based on analytics as to whether a potential breach was found.

priority_id.caption: Priority ID
priority_id.description: The normalized priority. Priority identifies the relative importance of the incident or finding. It is a measurement of urgency.

3.caption: High
3.description: Critical functionality or network access is interrupted, degraded or unusable, having a severe impact on services availability. No acceptable alternative is possible.

1.caption: Low
1.description: Application or personal procedure is unusable, where a workaround is available or a repair is possible.

2.caption: Medium
2.description: Non-critical function or procedure is unusable or hard to use causing operational disruptions with no direct impact on a service's availability. A workaround is available.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The priority is not normalized.

4.caption: Critical
4.description: Interruption making a critical functionality inaccessible or a complete network interruption causing a severe impact on services availability. There is no possible alternative.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: A Url link used to access the original incident.

tickets.caption: Tickets
tickets.description: The associated ticket(s) in the ticketing system. Each ticket contains details like ticket ID, status, etc.

verdict.caption: Verdict
verdict.description: The verdict assigned to an Incident finding.

verdict_id.caption: Verdict ID
verdict_id.description: The normalized verdict of an Incident.

3.caption: Disregard
3.description: The incident can be disregarded as it is unimportant, an error or accident.

6.caption: Test
6.description: The incident is a test.

1.caption: False Positive
1.description: The incident is a false positive.

2.caption: True Positive
2.description: The incident is a true positive.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: Suspicious
4.description: The incident is suspicious.

5.caption: Benign
5.description: The incident is benign.

7.caption: Insufficient Data
7.description: The incident has insufficient data to make a verdict.

8.caption: Security Risk
8.description: The incident is a security risk.

9.caption: Managed Externally
9.description: The incident remediation or required actions are managed externally.

10.caption: Duplicate
10.description: The incident is a duplicate.

linux/linux_users.caption: Linux Users
linux/linux_users.name: linux_users
linux/linux_users.description: The attributes that Linux uses to identify user information.

group.caption: Group
group.description: The group under which this process is running.

auid.caption: Audit User ID
auid.description: The audit user assigned at login by the audit subsystem.

egid.caption: Effective Group ID
egid.description: The effective group under which this process is running.

euid.caption: Effective User ID
euid.description: The effective user under which this process is running.

load_balancer.caption: Load Balancer
load_balancer.name: load_balancer
load_balancer.description: The attributes that describe information specific to load balancers.

load_balancer.caption: Load Balancer
load_balancer.description: The Load Balancer object contains information related to the device that is distributing incoming traffic to specified destinations.

network_proxy.caption: Network Proxy
network_proxy.name: network_proxy
network_proxy.description: The attributes that identify network proxy attributes.

proxy_connection_info.caption: Proxy Connection Info
proxy_connection_info.description: The connection information from the proxy server to the remote server.

proxy_endpoint.caption: Proxy Endpoint
proxy_endpoint.description: The proxy (server) in a network connection.

proxy_http_request.caption: Proxy HTTP Request
proxy_http_request.description: The HTTP Request from the proxy server to the remote server.

proxy_http_response.caption: Proxy HTTP Response
proxy_http_response.description: The HTTP Response from the remote server to the proxy server.

proxy_tls.caption: Proxy TLS
proxy_tls.description: The TLS protocol negotiated between the proxy server and the remote server.

proxy_traffic.caption: Proxy Traffic
proxy_traffic.description: The network traffic refers to the amount of data moving across a network, from proxy to remote server at a given point of time.

osint.caption: OSINT
osint.name: osint
osint.description: The OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) profile contains one or more indicators and associated analysis and details, such as registrar (WHOIS) information and commentary about a hostname, or information about a digital certificate and its usage within a campaign. This information can be used to further enrich a detection or finding by providing decisioning support to other analysts and engineers within the profile itself.

osint.caption: OSINT
osint.description: The OSINT (Open Source Intelligence) object contains details related to an indicator such as the indicator itself, related indicators, geolocation, registrar information, subdomains, analyst commentary, and other contextual information. This information can be used to further enrich a detection or finding by providing decisioning support to other analysts and engineers.

security_control.caption: Security Control
security_control.name: security_control
security_control.description: The attributes including disposition that represent the outcome of a security control including but not limited to access control, malware or policy violation, network proxy, intrusion detection, firewall, or data control. The profile is intended to augment activities or findings with an outcome when a security control has observed or intervened. If the control detected a security violation, and the disposition_id or action_id is an alertable outcome or action, the is_alert flag may be set to true.

disposition.caption: Disposition
disposition.description: The disposition name, normalized to the caption of the disposition_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

attacks.caption: MITRE ATT&CK® and ATLAS™ Details
attacks.description: An array of MITRE ATT&CK® objects describing identified tactics, techniques & sub-techniques. The objects are compatible with MITRE ATLAS™ tactics, techniques & sub-techniques.

disposition_id.caption: Disposition ID
disposition_id.description: Describes the outcome or action taken by a security control, such as access control checks, malware detections or various types of policy violations.

3.caption: Quarantined
3.description: A suspicious file or other content was moved to a benign location.

6.caption: Dropped
6.description: The request was detected as a threat and resulted in the connection being dropped.

1.caption: Allowed
1.description: Granted access or allowed the action to the protected resource.

2.caption: Blocked
2.description: Denied access or blocked the action to the protected resource.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The disposition is not mapped. See the disposition attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: Isolated
4.description: A session was isolated on the network or within a browser.

5.caption: Deleted
5.description: A file or other content was deleted.

7.caption: Custom Action
7.description: A custom action was executed such as running of a command script. Use the message attribute of the base class for details.

8.caption: Approved
8.description: A request or submission was approved. For example, when a form was properly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 1 'Allowed'.

9.caption: Restored
9.description: A quarantined file or other content was restored to its original location.

10.caption: Exonerated
10.description: A suspicious or risky entity was deemed to no longer be suspicious (re-scored).

11.caption: Corrected
11.description: A corrupt file or configuration was corrected.

12.caption: Partially Corrected
12.description: A corrupt file or configuration was partially corrected.

14.caption: Delayed
14.description: An operation was delayed, for example if a restart was required to finish the operation.

15.caption: Detected
15.description: Suspicious activity or a policy violation was detected without further action.

16.caption: No Action
16.description: The outcome of an operation had no action taken.

17.caption: Logged
17.description: The operation or action was logged without further action.

18.caption: Tagged
18.description: A file or other entity was marked with extended attributes.

20.caption: Count
20.description: Counted the request or activity but did not determine whether to allow it or block it.

21.caption: Reset
21.description: The request was detected as a threat and resulted in the connection being reset.

22.caption: Captcha
22.description: Required the end user to solve a CAPTCHA puzzle to prove that a human being is sending the request.

23.caption: Challenge
23.description: Ran a silent challenge that required the client session to verify that it's a browser, and not a bot.

24.caption: Access Revoked
24.description: The requestor's access has been revoked due to security policy enforcements. Note: use the Host profile if the User or Actor requestor is not present in the event class.

25.caption: Rejected
25.description: A request or submission was rejected. For example, when a form was improperly filled out and submitted. This is distinct from 2 'Blocked'.

26.caption: Unauthorized
26.description: An attempt to access a resource was denied due to an authorization check that failed. This is a more specific disposition than 2 'Blocked' and can be complemented with the authorizations attribute for more detail.

27.caption: Error
27.description: An error occurred during the processing of the activity or request. Use the message attribute of the base class for details.

13.caption: Uncorrected
13.description: A corrupt file or configuration was not corrected.

19.caption: Alert
19.description: The request or activity was detected as a threat and resulted in a notification but request was not blocked.

action_id.caption: Action ID
action_id.description: The action taken by a control or other policy-based system leading to an outcome or disposition. An unknown action may still correspond to a known disposition. Refer to disposition_id for the outcome of the action.

3.caption: Observed
3.description: The activity was observed, but neither explicitly allowed nor denied. This is common with IDS and EDR controls that report additional information on observed behavior such as TTPs. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Logged', 'Alert', 'Detected', 'Count', etc.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The action was unknown. The disposition_id attribute may still be set to a non-unknown value, for example 'Custom Action', 'Challenge'.

1.caption: Allowed
1.description: The activity was allowed. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Allowed', 'Approved', 'Delayed', 'No Action', 'Count' etc.

2.caption: Denied
2.description: The attempted activity was denied. The disposition_id attribute should be set to a value that conforms to this action, for example 'Blocked', 'Rejected', 'Quarantined', 'Isolated', 'Dropped', 'Access Revoked, etc.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The action is not mapped. See the action attribute which contains a data source specific value.

4.caption: Modified
4.description: The activity was modified, adjusted, or corrected. The disposition_id attribute should be set appropriately, for example 'Restored', 'Corrected', 'Delayed', 'Captcha', 'Tagged'.

authorizations.caption: Authorization Information
authorizations.description: Provides details about an authorization, such as authorization outcome, and any associated policies related to the activity/event.

confidence.caption: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence, normalized to the caption of the confidence_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

confidence_id.caption: Confidence ID
confidence_id.description: The normalized confidence refers to the accuracy of the rule that created the finding. A rule with a low confidence means that the finding scope is wide and may create finding reports that may not be malicious in nature.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The confidence is not mapped to the defined enum values. See the confidence attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

confidence_score.caption: Confidence Score
confidence_score.description: The confidence score as reported by the event source.

firewall_rule.caption: Firewall Rule
firewall_rule.description: The firewall rule that pertains to the control that triggered the event, if applicable.

is_alert.caption: Alert
is_alert.description: Indicates that the event is considered to be an alertable signal. Should be set to true if disposition_id = Alert among other dispositions, and/or risk_level_id or severity_id of the event is elevated. Not all control events will be alertable, for example if disposition_id = Exonerated or disposition_id = Allowed.

malware.caption: Malware
malware.description: A list of Malware objects, describing details about the identified malware.

malware_scan_info.caption: Malware Scan Info
malware_scan_info.description: Describes details about the scan job that identified malware on the target system.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.description: The policy that pertains to the control that triggered the event, if applicable. For example the name of an anti-malware policy or an access control policy.

risk_details.caption: Risk Details
risk_details.description: Describes the risk associated with the finding.

risk_level.caption: Risk Level
risk_level.description: The risk level, normalized to the caption of the risk_level_id value.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The risk level is not mapped. See the risk_level attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

risk_score.caption: Risk Score
risk_score.description: The risk score as reported by the event source.

trace.caption: Trace
trace.name: trace
trace.description: The Trace Profile extends the OCSF framework to capture and standardize observability events, specifically targeting trace-level data. This profile enables integration and normalization of distributed tracing information, allowing OCSF events to retain essential trace context such as trace IDs, span relationships, and service dependencies.

trace.caption: Trace
trace.description: The trace object contains information about distributed traces which are critical to observability and describe how requests move through a system, capturing each step's timing and status.

linux.name: linux
linux.caption: Linux
linux.description: The Linux extension defines Linux specific attributes, objects and classes.

win.name: win
win.caption: Windows
win.description: The Windows extension defines Windows specific attributes, objects and classes.

memory_activity.caption: Memory Activity
memory_activity.name: memory_activity
memory_activity.description: Memory Activity events report when a process has memory allocated, read/modified, or other manipulation activities - such as a buffer overflow or turning off data execution protection (DEP).

script_activity.caption: Script Activity
script_activity.name: script_activity
script_activity.description: Script Activity events report when a process executes a script.

scheduled_job_activity.caption: Scheduled Job Activity
scheduled_job_activity.name: scheduled_job_activity
scheduled_job_activity.description: Scheduled Job Activity events report activities related to scheduled jobs or tasks.

file_activity.caption: File System Activity
file_activity.name: file_activity
file_activity.description: File System Activity events report when a process performs an action on a file or folder.

process_activity.caption: Process Activity
process_activity.name: process_activity
process_activity.description: Process Activity events report when a process launches, injects, opens or terminates another process, successful or otherwise.

module_activity.caption: Module Activity
module_activity.name: module_activity
module_activity.description: Module Activity events report when a process loads or unloads the module.

kernel_activity.caption: Kernel Activity
kernel_activity.name: kernel_activity
kernel_activity.description: Kernel Activity events report when an process creates, reads, or deletes a kernel resource.

kernel_extension_activity.caption: Kernel Extension Activity
kernel_extension_activity.name: kernel_extension_activity
kernel_extension_activity.description: Kernel Extension events report when a driver/extension is loaded or unloaded into the kernel

event_log_actvity.caption: Event Log Activity
event_log_actvity.name: event_log_actvity
event_log_actvity.description: Event Log Activity events report actions pertaining to the system's event logging service(s), such as disabling logging or clearing the log data.

win/windows_service_activity.caption: Windows Service Activity
win/windows_service_activity.name: windows_service_activity
win/windows_service_activity.description: Windows Service Activity events report when a process interacts with the Service Control Manager.

win/registry_value_activity.caption: Registry Value Activity
win/registry_value_activity.name: registry_value_activity
win/registry_value_activity.description: Registry Value Activity events reports when a process performs an action on a Windows registry value.

win/windows_resource_activity.caption: Windows Resource Activity
win/windows_resource_activity.name: windows_resource_activity
win/windows_resource_activity.description: Windows Resource Activity events report when a process accesses a Windows managed resource object, successful or otherwise.

win/registry_key_activity.caption: Registry Key Activity
win/registry_key_activity.name: registry_key_activity
win/registry_key_activity.description: Registry Key Activity events report when a process performs an action on a Windows registry key.

application.name: application
application.caption: Application Activity
application.description: Application Activity events report detailed information about the behavior of applications and services.

datastore_activity.caption: Datastore Activity
datastore_activity.name: datastore_activity
datastore_activity.description: Datastore events describe general activities (Read, Update, Query, Delete, etc.) which affect datastores or data within those datastores, e.g. (AWS RDS, AWS S3).

application_lifecycle.caption: Application Lifecycle
application_lifecycle.name: application_lifecycle
application_lifecycle.description: Application Lifecycle events report installation, removal, start, stop of an application or service.

application_error.caption: Application Error
application_error.name: application_error
application_error.description: Application Error events describe issues with an applications. The error message should be put in the event's message attribute. The metadata.product attribute can be used to capture the originating application information. The host profile can used to include the generating device information. This class is helpful (and originally intended for) applications that generate and/or handle OCSF events. This class can also be used for errors in upstream products and services.

file_hosting.caption: File Hosting Activity
file_hosting.name: file_hosting
file_hosting.description: File Hosting Activity events report the actions taken by file management applications, including file sharing servers like Sharepoint and services such as Box, MS OneDrive, Google Drive, or network file share services.

api_activity.caption: API Activity
api_activity.name: api_activity
api_activity.description: API events describe general CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) API activities, e.g. (AWS Cloudtrail)

web_resource_access_activity.caption: Web Resource Access Activity
web_resource_access_activity.name: web_resource_access_activity
web_resource_access_activity.description: Web Resource Access Activity events describe successful/failed attempts to access a web resource over HTTP.

scan_activity.caption: Scan Activity
scan_activity.name: scan_activity
scan_activity.description: Scan events report the start, completion, and results of a scan job. The scan event includes the number of items that were scanned and the number of detections that were resolved.

web_resources_activity.caption: Web Resources Activity
web_resources_activity.name: web_resources_activity
web_resources_activity.description: Web Resources Activity events describe actions executed on a set of Web Resources.

discovery.name: discovery
discovery.caption: Discovery
discovery.description: Discovery events report the existence and state of devices, files, configurations, processes, registry keys, and other objects.

session_query.caption: User Session Query
session_query.name: session_query
session_query.description: User Session Query events report information about existing user sessions.

software_info.caption: Software Inventory Info
software_info.name: software_info
software_info.description: Software Inventory Info events report device software inventory data that is either logged or proactively collected. For example, when collecting device information from a CMDB or running a network sweep of connected devices.

networks_query.caption: Networks Query
networks_query.name: networks_query
networks_query.description: Networks Query events report information about network adapters.

osint_inventory_info.caption: OSINT Inventory Info
osint_inventory_info.name: osint_inventory_info
osint_inventory_info.description: OSINT Inventory Info events report open source intelligence or threat intelligence inventory data that is either logged or proactively collected. For example, when collecting OSINT information from Threat Intelligence Platforms (TIPs) or Extended Detection and Response (XDR) platforms, or collecting data from OSINT or other generic threat intelligence and enrichment feeds such as APIs and datastores.

device_config_state_change.caption: Device Config State Change
device_config_state_change.name: device_config_state_change
device_config_state_change.description: Device Config State Change events report state changes that impact the security of the device.

kernel_object_query.caption: Kernel Object Query
kernel_object_query.name: kernel_object_query
kernel_object_query.description: Kernel Object Query events report information about discovered kernel resources.

cloud_resources_inventory_info.caption: Cloud Resources Inventory Info
cloud_resources_inventory_info.name: cloud_resources_inventory_info
cloud_resources_inventory_info.description: Cloud Resources Inventory Info events report cloud asset inventory data. This data can be either logged or proactively collected. For example, use this event class when creating an inventory of cloud resource information from a Configuration Management Database (CMDB), Cyber Asset Attack Surface Management (CAASM), direct public cloud service provider APIs, Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) APIs, or otherwise.

file_query.caption: File Query
file_query.name: file_query
file_query.description: File Query events report information about files that are present on the system.

folder_query.caption: Folder Query
folder_query.name: folder_query
folder_query.description: Folder Query events report information about folders that are present on the system.

user_query.caption: User Query
user_query.name: user_query
user_query.description: User Query events report user data that have been discovered, queried, polled or searched. This event differs from User Inventory as it describes the result of a targeted search by filtering a subset of user attributes.

user_inventory.caption: User Inventory Info
user_inventory.name: user_inventory
user_inventory.description: User Inventory Info events report user inventory data that is either logged or proactively collected. For example, when collecting user information from Active Directory entries.

evidence_info.caption: Live Evidence Info
evidence_info.name: evidence_info
evidence_info.description: Data collected directly from devices that represents forensic information pulled, queried, or discovered from devices that may indicate malicious activity. It contains a number of child objects, each representing a distinct evidence domain (network connections, file artifacts, registry entries, etc.). When mapping raw telemetry data users should select Query Evidence and then the appropriate child object that best matches the evidence type.

network_connection_query.caption: Network Connection Query
network_connection_query.name: network_connection_query
network_connection_query.description: Network Connection Query events report information about active network connections.

module_query.caption: Module Query
module_query.name: module_query
module_query.description: Module Query events report information about loaded modules.

process_query.caption: Process Query
process_query.name: process_query
process_query.description: Process Query events report information about running processes.

inventory_info.caption: Device Inventory Info
inventory_info.name: inventory_info
inventory_info.description: Device Inventory Info events report device inventory data that is either logged or proactively collected. For example, when collecting device information from a CMDB or running a network sweep of connected devices.

admin_group_query.caption: Admin Group Query
admin_group_query.name: admin_group_query
admin_group_query.description: Admin Group Query events report information about administrative groups.

config_state.caption: Device Config State
config_state.name: config_state
config_state.description: Device Config State events report device configuration data, device assessments, and/or CIS Benchmark results.

startup_item_query.caption: Startup Item Query
startup_item_query.name: startup_item_query
startup_item_query.description: Startup Item Query events report information about discovered items, e.g., application components that are generally configured to run automatically.

service_query.caption: Service Query
service_query.name: service_query
service_query.description: Service Query events report information about running services.

job_query.caption: Job Query
job_query.name: job_query
job_query.description: Job Query events report information about scheduled jobs.

peripheral_device_query.caption: Peripheral Device Query
peripheral_device_query.name: peripheral_device_query
peripheral_device_query.description: Peripheral Device Query events report information about peripheral devices.

patch_state.caption: Operating System Patch State
patch_state.name: patch_state
patch_state.description: Operating System Patch State reports the installation of an OS patch to a device and any associated knowledgebase articles.

win/registry_key_query.caption: Registry Key Query
win/registry_key_query.name: registry_key_query
win/registry_key_query.description: Registry Key Query events report information about discovered Windows registry keys.

win/registry_value_query.caption: Registry Value Query
win/registry_value_query.name: registry_value_query
win/registry_value_query.description: Registry Value Query events report information about discovered Windows registry values.

win/prefetch_query.caption: Prefetch Query
win/prefetch_query.name: prefetch_query
win/prefetch_query.description: Prefetch Query events report information about Windows prefetch files.

findings.name: findings
findings.caption: Findings
findings.description: Findings events report findings, detections, and possible resolutions of malware, anomalies, or other actions performed by security products.

application_security_posture_finding.caption: Application Security Posture Finding
application_security_posture_finding.name: application_security_posture_finding
application_security_posture_finding.description:
The Application Security Posture Finding event is a notification about any bug, defect, deficiency, exploit, vulnerability, weakness or any other issue with software and related systems. Application Security Posture Findings typically involve reporting on the greater context including compliance, impacted resources, remediation guidance, specific code defects, and/or vulnerability metadata. Application Security Posture Findings can be reported by Threat & Vulnerability Management (TVM) tools, Application Security Posture Management (ASPM) tools, or other similar tools. Note: if the event producer is a security control, the security_control profile should be applied and its attacks information, if present, should be duplicated into the finding_info object.
Note: If the Finding is an incident, i.e. requires incident workflow, also apply the incident profile or aggregate this finding into an Incident Finding.

incident_finding.caption: Incident Finding
incident_finding.name: incident_finding
incident_finding.description:
An Incident Finding reports the creation, update, or closure of security incidents as a result of detections and/or analytics.
Note: Incident Finding implicitly includes the incident profile and it should be added to the metadata.profiles[] array.

security_finding.caption: Security Finding
security_finding.name: security_finding
security_finding.description: Security Finding events describe findings, detections, anomalies, alerts and/or actions performed by security products

data_security_finding.caption: Data Security Finding
data_security_finding.name: data_security_finding
data_security_finding.description:
A Data Security Finding describes detections or alerts generated by various data security products such as Data Loss Prevention (DLP), Data Classification, Secrets Management, Digital Rights Management (DRM), Data Security Posture Management (DSPM), and similar tools. These detections or alerts can be created using fingerprinting, statistical analysis, machine learning or other methodologies. The finding describes the actors and endpoints who accessed or own the sensitive data, as well as the resources which store the sensitive data. Note: if the event producer is a security control, the security_control profile should be applied and its attacks information, if present, should be duplicated into the finding_info object.
Note: If the Finding is an incident, i.e. requires incident workflow, also apply the incident profile or aggregate this finding into an Incident Finding.

detection_finding.caption: Detection Finding
detection_finding.name: detection_finding
detection_finding.description:
A Detection Finding describes detections or alerts generated by security products using correlation engines, detection engines or other methodologies. Note: if the event producer is a security control, the security_control profile should be applied and its attacks information, if present, should be duplicated into the finding_info object.
Note: If the Finding is an incident, i.e. requires incident workflow, also apply the incident profile or aggregate this finding into an Incident Finding.

compliance_finding.caption: Compliance Finding
compliance_finding.name: compliance_finding
compliance_finding.description:
Compliance Finding events describe results of evaluations performed against resources, to check compliance with various Industry Frameworks or Security Standards such as NIST SP 800-53, CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark v1.4.0, ISO/IEC 27001 etc. Note: if the event producer is a security control, the security_control profile should be applied and its attacks information, if present, should be duplicated into the finding_info object.
Note: If the Finding is an incident, i.e. requires incident workflow, also apply the incident profile or aggregate this finding into an Incident Finding.

vulnerability_finding.caption: Vulnerability Finding
vulnerability_finding.name: vulnerability_finding
vulnerability_finding.description:
The Vulnerability Finding event is a notification about weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, or implementation that could be exploited or triggered by a threat source. Note: if the event producer is a security control, the security_control profile should be applied and its attacks information, if present, should be duplicated into the finding_info object.
Note: If the Finding is an incident, i.e. requires incident workflow, also apply the incident profile or aggregate this finding into an Incident Finding.

iam.name: iam
iam.caption: Identity & Access Management
iam.description: Identity & Access Management (IAM) events relate to the supervision of the system's authentication and access control model. Examples of such events are the success or failure of authentication, granting of authority, password change, entity change, privileged use etc.

authentication.caption: Authentication
authentication.name: authentication
authentication.description: Authentication events report authentication session activities, including user attempts to log on or log off, regardless of success, as well as other key stages within the authentication process. These events are typically generated by authentication services, such as Kerberos, OIDC, or SAML, and may include information about the user, the authentication method used, and the status of the authentication attempt.

account_change.caption: Account Change
account_change.name: account_change
account_change.description: Account Change events report when specific user account management tasks are performed, such as a user/role being created, changed, deleted, renamed, disabled, enabled, locked out or unlocked.

authorize_session.caption: Authorize Session
authorize_session.name: authorize_session
authorize_session.description: Authorize Session events report privileges or groups assigned to a new user session, usually at login time.

entity_management.caption: Entity Management
entity_management.name: entity_management
entity_management.description: Entity Management events report activity by a managed client, a micro service, or a user at a management console. The activity can be a create, read, update, and delete operation on a managed entity.

group_management.caption: Group Management
group_management.name: group_management
group_management.description: Group Management events report management updates to a group, including updates to membership and permissions.

user_access.caption: User Access Management
user_access.name: user_access
user_access.description: User Access Management events report management updates to a user's privileges.

tunnel_activity.caption: Tunnel Activity
tunnel_activity.name: tunnel_activity
tunnel_activity.description: Tunnel Activity events report secure tunnel establishment (such as VPN), teardowns, renewals, and other network tunnel specific actions.

network_file_activity.caption: Network File Activity
network_file_activity.name: network_file_activity
network_file_activity.description: Network File Activity events report file activities traversing the network, including file storage services such as Box, MS OneDrive, or Google Drive.

email_activity.caption: Email Activity
email_activity.name: email_activity
email_activity.description: Email Activity events report SMTP protocol and email activities including those with embedded URLs and files. See the Email object for details.

rdp_activity.caption: RDP Activity
rdp_activity.name: rdp_activity
